MR CHIAM SEE TONG
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


     Mr Speaker: Order. On 20th August 1993, I received a letter dated 20th August 1993 from the Acting Secretary-General of the Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) informing me that Mr Chiam See Tong has been expelled from the Singapore Democratic Party with immediate effect.

    On 21st August 1993, the Clerk of Parliament wrote to Mr Chiam referring to

Column: 396

this letter and asking Mr Chiam to confirm immediately that he had been so expelled from the Singapore Democratic Party.

    Mr Chiam replied on 21st August 1993 to state that the Central Executive Committee of the SDP had sent him a letter on 20th August 1993 to expel him from the Party, but that the SDP letter was not valid and was illegal, and that the Supreme Authority of the SDP was the Party Conference comprising all the cadres. Mr Chiam also stated that a Special Party Conference had been requisitioned by cadres of the Party but that the Central Executive Committee had failed to convene such a Conference but instead had proceeded to expel him. He maintained that the Central Executive Committee's act of sacking him was unconstitutional and illegal.

    Mr Chiam therefore requested that the Speaker "holds his hands until the legality of my expulsion from the SDP is decided at the next Party Conference of the SDP, which has already been properly requisitioned."

    Subsequently, on 27th August 1993, Mr Chiam wrote to me to say that on 25th August 1993 he had obtained an Order of Injunction from the Courts against the Central Executive Committee of the SDP restraining them from expelling him from the Party. He attached a copy of the Court Order in his letter to me.

    In view of these developments, in particular Mr Chiam's contention that his expulsion was illegal and the steps he has taken to challenge the validity of the expulsion, it is not appropriate for me to ask Parliament to take any decision until the parties have resolved these issues.

     Mr Speaker: I wish to take this opportunity to place on record the deaths of Dr Yeoh Ghim Seng, former Speaker of Parliament on 3rd June 1993, and of Dr Tay Eng Soon, former Senior Minister of State for Education and Member for Eunos GRC, on 5th August 1993.

    I desire on behalf of the House to express our sense of the loss we have

Column: 397

sustained and our sympathy with the families of the late Dr Yeoh Ghim Seng and Dr Tay Eng Soon.

Column: 397

OBITUARY ON THE LATE DR YEOH GHIM SENG AND THE LATE DR TAY ENG SOON


     The Leader of the House (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, we are sojourners on this earth. No day is promised to any of us. For so long as we are on this earth, we try to make the best use of our time, in the best way that we could. Many of us would use that time for ourselves, for our families. That is to be expected. Some would simply waste it, but then that is their own look out, as it is their life. But there are some who not only make full use of their time and life for themselves and their families, they also give much of their time to others. They give to others more than they receive. Dr Yeoh Ghim Seng, our former Speaker, and Dr Tay Eng Soon, our former colleague, were two such rare individuals.

    Dr Yeoh Ghim Seng passed away on 3rd June this year, after a period of illness. Dr Yeoh was elected as MP for Joo Chiat in 1966, during the turbulent years of early independent Singapore. He had remained as a Member for Joo Chiat constituency until the

1988    General Elections. He retired after serving nearly 22 years for the nation.

    Within less than two years of being elected as an MP for Joo Chiat, Dr Yeoh was elected as Deputy Speaker in July 1968, and then as Speaker in January 1970, an appointment he held until January 1989. As our longest serving Speaker from 1970 to 1989, he guided Singapore through one of its most constructive phases of development.

    For those of us who were in this House when Dr Yeoh Ghim Seng was the Speaker, we fondly remember him as a Speaker who exercised his responsibility with fairness and firmness. He brought decorum, dignity and esteem to the office of Speaker. He had always been indulgent and patient with the Members.

    Dr Yeoh was not only well-known for his distinguished contribution to Singapore as a

Column: 398

Parliamentarian and Speaker but was also renowned for his excellent surgical skills in the medical fraternity in Singapore and in the region. He was the first Singaporean to be appointed Professor of Surgery at the then University of Malaya in 1955. Because of his contribution to medicine in Singapore, a Yeoh Ghim Seng Professorship in Surgery was instituted in his name by his former students and well-wishers.

    Dr Yeoh had not only won the respect of this House but also that of all Singaporeans. We send our deepest condolence to the family of the late Dr Yeoh.

    As for Dr Tay Eng Soon, his death came as a shock to me when I heard of it at Parliament Annexe on 5th August this year. Some of our MPs who were with me at the time were equally shocked and saddened by the news.

    Dr Tay was first elected to Parliament in 1980 in the constituency of River Valley. With the changes in the constituency boundaries, Dr Tay was supposed to contest in Tanglin in the 1988 General Elections. However, the call of duty demanded a last minute switch for him to lead the PAP team to contest in the Eunos GRC. Like any of our PAP's loyal and dedicated members, he stoutly took on the task. He knew that it was a tough fight but he took it in his stride. Dr Tay and his team won the 1988 General Elections in Eunos. They continued to toil the ground and improved the percentage of votes in 1991.

    Dr Tay made significant contributions in education, in particular, technical education. But Dr Tay's contribution was not just confined to education only. He held a number of other posts. He found time to serve in the PAP Community Foundation and the National Kidney Foundation. With his departure from this world, he left many vacancies to be filled.

    Dr Tay's dedication to his work, constituency and family is known to all of us. Even when Dr Tay was in hospital, his mind was still on his work. Colleagues who had visited him in the hospital would testify to the fact that Dr Tay would discuss affairs of state with them despite

Column: 399

the pain that he was suffering. Even when he was in hospital just before his death, he was preparing his National Day speech for his constituency's National Day Dinner which he had hoped to attend. But, alas, he could not keep that appointment because his illness overcame him. We send our deepest condolence to Dr Tay's bereaved family.

    On behalf of the Members, I would like to place on record the appreciation of this House for the significant contributions of both Dr Yeoh Ghim Seng and Dr Tay Eng Soon. We mourn their loss.

     Mr Speaker: As a mark of respect to the late Dr Yeoh Ghim Seng and the late Dr Tay Eng Soon, I propose that the House observe a two-minute silence.

    The House rose and paid respect.

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SINGLE UNSUPPORTED AGED HDB FLAT RESIDENTS
(Assistance)


    1. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development if he will give the number of single unsupported aged persons living in Housing and Development Board rental flats and whether there are plans to assist these residents in their living arrangements and facilities.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, at present, there are about 10,800 elderly households living in HDB rental flats. About 6,000 are living in 1-room flats. Elderly persons are those aged 60 years and above. These elderly households consist of either a single elderly person living alone, two elderly single persons sharing a flat, or an elderly couple living on their own. In many of these cases, particularly the early immigrants, the elderly residents have to fend for themselves.

    If nothing is done to assist these elderly households in their living arrangements and facilities, in such a way as to enhance

Column: 400

their mobility and independence, many of these elderly persons will be prematurely forced to go into institutional care. We should make it possible for the elderly to live in the community for as long as possible.

    I am pleased to announce that my Ministry has, in conjunction with the Ministry of Community Development (MCD), worked out a scheme to carry out improvement works to upgrade the living conditions of the elderly staying in 1-room rental flats. Suitable 1-room rental blocks with high concentrations of elderly households will be selected for the improvement works, which include modification of lifts to stop at every floor, making the bathrooms and toilets non-slip, replacement of existing taps with taps that have 'lift up' handles, and support handbars in the toilets.

    To kick off the scheme, a pilot project will be implemented in three blocks where more than a quarter of the households are elderly households. The three blocks are:

    Blk 5 Banda Street;

    Blk 4 Telok Blangah Crescent; and

    Blk 90 Pipit Road.

    HDB will also work with MCD to arrange for a voluntary welfare organisation to provide community-based care and support services such as home-help services, meals and goods delivery services, and Befriender services, to the elderly households in each block. An administrative office will be set up at each block to facilitate the work of the respective voluntary organisations.

    In this way, the elderly residents can continue to live independently, while at the same time being assured of help if needed.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, are the residents required to pay for the internal improvements in their flats?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: These internal improvements will be entirely funded by the Government.

     Mr Loh Meng See (Kampong Glam GRC): Sir, is it the intention of the Ministry

Column: 401

to group all these elderly citizens together so that they can benefit from the scheme? How long will the total project of the pilot scheme last, and when will we see that every elderly citizen will benefit from the improvements?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: For this scheme to work, we require two things to come together. First, the physical improvements to the flat to make it more convenient for the elderly to live independently. Secondly, a strong welfare support system so that services are extended to them if needed, such as the Befriender service, etc. So this scheme can only work if these two things come together and we have to work closely with the Advisor to the Citizens' Consultative Committee in each constituency to try and encourage them to set up such voluntary services. Right now, there is no firm intention to group all the elderly in a constituency in one block. We leave it to the Advisor. In discussing this pilot scheme with some of the Advisors, some prefer to keep up to maybe half of the block for the senior citizens and the other half for the normal households so that the block has a mix. Other Advisors are prepared to have a higher percentage. We will leave it to the Advisor to decide what percentage he feels comfortable. We also leave it to the Advisor to work with the voluntary organisations to make the scheme work.

SINGAPORE'S INVOLVEMENT IN REGIONAL GROUPINGS
(Objectives and roles)


    The following question stood in the name of Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew -

    2. To ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs what are Singapore's objectives and roles in our involvement in the various regional groupings, such as the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, Asia Pacific Economic Co-operation, East Asian Economic Caucus, etc.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck (Nominated Member): On behalf of Mr Robert Chua, Question No. 2, Sir.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, no country is big enough to stand alone.

Column: 402

Even for the United States, it needs to be part of a larger North America Free Trade Area. The industrial economies have an exclusive club, the Group of Seven (G7). They meet annually at Heads of Government level, most recently in Tokyo.

    Singapore's prosperity and security depend heavily on its trade, investment and political links with its Asian neighbours and the industrial economies. Our membership in regional groupings like ASEAN, APEC and the EAEC, etc. is essential to our prosperity and well-being. Our objectives are to ensure friendly political relations and economic cooperation with our neighbours and economic partners, who are also members of these groupings. They provide us with a network of friends and partners which helps us to protect our interests and creates new economic opportunities.

    Singapore plays an active role in ASEAN and APEC, and we would do our part in helping the EAEC to take off. This active role gives us a stake in regional and international developments.

    While the recent ASEAN Ministerial Meeting and the Post-Ministerial Conferences are still fresh in our minds, let me use them as an illustration. Between the ASEAN Summit and last month's ASEAN-PMC Ministerial Meetings, both chaired by Singapore, ASEAN has made significant progress in regional political and economic cooperation that serves the interests of Singapore and its ASEAN partners.

    In order to meet the challenges of large economic groupings that may shut us out, and to deal with geopolitical uncertainties arising from the end of the Cold War, we have:

    Firstly, agreed on an ASEAN Free Trade Area;

    Secondly, strengthened our links with major economic partners like the US, Japan, China and the NIEs through APEC. We can help to develop APEC's links because the Secretariat has been set up in Singapore; and

    Thirdly, started new networks for consultations on regional security, both

Column: 403

within ASEAN and with the major countries of the Asia-Pacific, which can reduce future uncertainties.

    The Government intends to continue to be active and constructive in ASEAN, APEC and the EAEC because they serve the interests of Singapore and its neighbours. Other regions, including Europe, have found it valuable to participate in the pattern of dialogue and cooperation ASEAN has established. ASEAN is not alone in moving in this direction. There is a global recognition that multilateral links have and will become more important in the post-Cold War era.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin (Nominated Member): Sir, with so many groupings, would the Minister consider the existence of a high-powered coordinating committee to see where our economic interests coalesce and where they conflict?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, there is no need for such a high-powered coordinating committee because all this work in dealing with external parties and our partners in ASEAN, APEC, etc., is coordinated by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

HAWKER STALLS
(Transfer to spouses or children)


    3. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for the Environment, in view of the policy to increasingly privatise hawker centres, whether he will consider allowing hawkers to transfer their stalls to their spouses or children instead of letting them remain vacant.

     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Sir, in the past, stalls were allotted to the poor and to resettle street hawkers to help them earn a living. As such, the stalls were heavily subsidised to keep rents low. They still are. It has therefore been necessary to make the stalls non-transferable. However, on compassionate grounds, my Ministry does allow an immediate family member of a deceased hawker to continue renting

Column: 404

the stall, if the family depends on the stall for a living. Between January 1992 and June 1993, there were 385 of such requests from family members of deceased hawkers. Of these, 353 or 92% were approved. The remaining cases were not approved as the families were not dependent on the stalls for a living.

    As recently announced by the Prime Minister, the Government plans to sell stalls to incumbent hawkers. After they own their stalls, these hawkers can sell, transfer or sub-let their stalls to others. Details of the sales scheme are being worked out.

REVISED PRIMARY ONE REGISTRATION SCHEME


    4. Mr Lew Syn Pau asked the Minister for Education how many children (percentage) were admitted at each phase of the revised Primary One Registration Scheme; how does this compare to the previous scheme; and whether he is satisfied that the revised scheme is more successful than the previous one.

     The Minister for Education (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Sir, as 1992 was the transition year, it is appropriate to compare the registration exercise in 1993 under the revised registration scheme with that in 1991 under the previous scheme.

    The new registration scheme focuses on the child's educational needs. It is desirable for siblings to study in the same school. Thus, the highest priority or Phase 1 is for a child with a sibling in the same school. In 1993, the percentage registered under Phase 1 is 41% as compared to 37% in 1991. The increase of four percentage points indicates that more children will study in the same primary school as their brothers and sisters. This is as it should be.

    Phases 2A and 2B provide for children with other school connections. Previously, it also gave priority to children whose parents had followed various family planning policies. The percentage registered under these phases has declined from 15% in 1991 to 13% in 1993. Schools are thus admitting more children who live in the neighbourhood.

Column: 405



     Mr Lew Syn Pau (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I understand from reports in the press that some parents abused the new system by falsely declaring their place of residence, or that their children are fostered out. Would the Minister tell the House whether this was a serious problem and, if so, how he intends to prevent such recurrences in the future?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, I think the Member is referring to recent press reports about parents who made false statutory declarations about foster help or leaving their children with families in the neighbourhood of popular schools. There were some who also had addresses nearby and these were suspect. My Ministry has come out with a press statement. We take a serious view of such matters. We are still in the process of investigating. If there are any cases that are found to have abused the system, we will follow up with appropriate action. We are also in the process of reviewing the guidelines to see whether from next year there should be some changes to avoid such abuses.

COLLISION OF MRT TRAINS AT CLEMENTI STATION


    5. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Communications what safety measures he has taken following the collision of two Mass Rapid Transit trains at Clementi Station recently.

     The Minister for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the accident took place at 7.46 am on 5th August 1993, when a westbound train from Buona Vista Station collided into the rear of the preceding train which had stalled at Clementi Station.

    After the accident, MRTC engineers conducted comprehensive tests to ascertain that all equipment along the affected stretch were working properly before allowing SMRT to resume train service between Queenstown and Jurong East Stations the following morning on 6th August 1993. However, as a precautionary measure, the resumption of the train service was subject to the restriction of not allowing a westbound train at

Column: 406

Buona Vista Station to leave until the preceding train at Clementi Station had moved off. This restriction was only lifted on 8th August 1993 after MRTC had performed a further round of checks on the system.

    A three-member Inquiry Panel has been appointed by MRTC to determine the causes of the accident, and to review the existing operating procedures and safety systems of the MRT system. The Inquiry Panel commenced its investigation on 10th August 1993. It expects to complete its task in a month's time.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Newspaper reports have said that the accident may be caused by electronic pollution. Can the Minister clarify on this point?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: I presume the Member is referring to a letter in the newspapers postulating that electronic pollution was the probable cause. The MRTC has assured me that in the planning of the system in the initial phase, electronic pollution was a factor that was taken into account as being a possible danger to the system. Therefore, all safeguards to protect the system from such a possibility were taken. Nevertheless, this is not to be discounted and the Inquiry Panel will, I am sure, look into this, amongst other factors.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, whilst waiting for the Report of the Inquiry Panel to come out, can the Minister throw some light on the possible causes of the accident?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: One of the possible causes was due to oil on the tracks immediately prior to the accident. Precautions that have to be taken by the MRTC and the SMRT to deal with oil spillage have been in the manuals. However, the fact that there was an excessive amount of oil being discovered on the tracks has created the possibility that this was a major cause of the accident. Nevertheless, I would not like to confirm this fact until the Inquiry Panel has had time to go further into this. In the meantime, extra precautions have been taken on how to deal with oil spillage on the tracks.

     The Minister for Labour (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Sir, the number of CPF contributors who used their savings to invest in the Stock Exchange of Singapore is as follows:

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Tampines GRC): Sir, is the Minister aware that, in view of the liberalisation of the scheme where capital gains may be withdrawn from CPF, a certain level of price fixing or manipulation is possible, and is he confident that the CPF Board and the computer system are adequate in coping with the task of keeping track?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the arrangement to allow CPF members to withdraw their capital gains from their investments in stocks and shares should not result in a greater opportunity for price-fixing by any individuals or group of individuals.
